instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..

threads.title: Macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green orange light, no fan, no boot
at first it did not turn on with battery, so I changed the smc but since no more starting
no short, no liquid damage

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3,42v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8,6v
<SIGNAL>P3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3,3v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>SMC_SENSOR_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> 3,42v

I changed several times smc but same result

threads.title: Macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Don't change components without reason.
Put logic in the repair process.

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>?
If yes, trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).

threads.title: Macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3,3v
 <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> 3,42 constant.
 when I trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> = 0,35v

threads.title: Macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Does it come back to 3V, when release <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?

Check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, at same time.

threads.title: Macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
yes come back
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0v

threads.title: Macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
No pulse at all at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>?
Remember to check it at same time when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: Macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message: no pulse  even with   <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>,  <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>  stay at 0V

threads.title: Macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Then you have a PCH related problem.
Check first its basic requirments; <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> and the 4 RTC (DC) signals.

threads.title: Macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>  0v"
PCH can't start power on sequence then.
Are you using original Magsafe 2 charger?

BTW, apart of <SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, I don't see other RTC DC signal listed.
Are not there 3 other lines EXACTLY near it on the same PCH RTC block?
I didn't ask for power, nor RTC clock.

threads.title: Macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PCH_CLK32K_RTCX1</SIGNAL> 0,43
<SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_CAMERA</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_TBT</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> 2,90v
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> 3,20v

yes with original charger, same with other charger same result, can you give me the signals you need? Sorry I'm still harmful compared to you

when I took the voltage on <SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL>, the motherboad turned and the fan turned hard and the processor heated normally, it's like I had woken it up I think maybe I touched <SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> at the same time without do it on purpose between <RESISTOR>R1302</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R1303</RESISTOR>

I took the charger out and put it back in but it won't start.

sorry for my English I am French

Check if starts in SMC bypass mode.

threads.message:
Check if reacts again when touch any RTC signals with multimeter.

Reflow SMC, in case of bad solders.

threads.title: Macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Still 0V on <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>?
If yes, check <RESISTOR>R1410</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: Macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
oui <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 0v, <RESISTOR>R1410</RESISTOR> dessoudé 10kohms, <RESISTOR>R1410</RESISTOR> soudé 2,5kohms
<RESISTOR>R1410</RESISTOR> pin 1 : 3,3, pin 2 : 0v, the resistor alone is 10k, but 2k when soldered, mode diod pin 2:  2,2 it's a short?

threads.title: Macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message: i removed smc, <RESISTOR>R1410</RESISTOR> came back to 10k and no shorts, smc was bad then, or badly soldered?

threads.title: Macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
"mode diod pin 2:  2,2 it's a short?"
PLEASE, post accurate information!
2.200 in diode mode (to ground), or what?
002.2 is short...

Be aware, resistors value measured onboard can differ a lot in respect of nominal value.
Other components create parasitic resistors, which change the expected reading.

threads.title: Macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message: I replaced the smc everything works again thanks for the help
